rows.title: Think about today

transcript.eng:
Close your eyes. 

Take a minute to think about the day.

Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
Praise yourself for one thing you did well today. 
Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.  
Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

rows.transcript:
Close your eyes. 

Take a minute to think about the day.

Think about one positive or fun thing you did.
Praise yourself for one thing you did well today. 
Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.  
Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. And amazing that you are using this app – it shows your commitment as a parent. Make sure you give yourself credit and praise for what you are doing.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Sometimes things go great and sometimes they do not. Sometimes we do not quite know what to think... and that is totally okay!  Praise yourself for being here on this app and trying – you are moving forward.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry to hear that things are difficult right now. Take a deep breath and know that you are valued by your family and friends.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Trying to finish all your daily tasks can be stressful. Make a list of the important things you have to do today to make it easier for you.

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Trying to finish all your daily tasks can make you tired. Make a list of the important things you have to do today to make it easier for you.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Great. And amazing that you are using this app – it shows your commitment as a parent. Make sure you give yourself credit and praise for what you are doing.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Sometimes things go great and sometimes they do not. Sometimes we do not quite know what to think... and that is totally okay!  Praise yourself for being here on this app and trying – you are moving forward.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sorry to hear that things are difficult right now. Take a deep breath and know that you are valued by your family and friends.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Trying to finish all your daily tasks can be stressful. Make a list of the important things you have to do today to make it easier for you.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: Trying to finish all your daily tasks can make you tired. Make a list of the important things you have to do today to make it easier for you.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's lesson is about learning to give instructions that work! 

Nobody follows rules all of the time. But *how* we give instructions can make things happier and calmer at home.

Negative instructions like, “Don’t touch that!” can make children feel bad. (They can make parents feel bad, too!)

Children are more likely to follow an instruction when it is worded in a positive way: "Please only touch things that don't belong to us!"

media_title.eng: How will this help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's lesson is about learning to give instructions that work! 

Nobody follows rules all of the time. But *how* we give instructions can make things happier and calmer at home.

Negative instructions like, “Don’t touch that!” can make children feel bad. (They can make parents feel bad, too!)

Children are more likely to follow an instruction when it is worded in a positive way: "Please only touch things that don't belong to us!"
rows.media_title: How will this help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name gives instructions to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name:

character_1_text.eng: It looks like you’re having a lot of fun, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. It’s almost time to clean up. In 3 minutes, please put your blocks away.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name gives instructions to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name:
rows.character_1_text: It looks like you’re having a lot of fun, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. It’s almost time to clean up. In 3 minutes, please put your blocks away.

character_1_text.eng: 3 minutes are over, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Please pack away your blocks.

rows.character_1_text: 3 minutes are over, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Please pack away your blocks.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.

rows.character_1_text: Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what we can learn from @data.characters.f1_father.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name.

quiz_1_question.eng: How does @data.characters.f1_father.name connect with @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name before giving an instruction?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: He does say his daughter’s name, but he also goes down to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name’s level, and gives her praise.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He reminds @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name that she has a responsibility to keep her toys clean.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_father.name does not just give an instruction right away, he first makes sure @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name feels seen!

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He starts cleaning up the blocks for @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to set an example.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_father.name first connects with his daughter by saying her name, getting down at her level, and giving her praise. This puts him in the best position to then give @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name an instruction.

quiz_2_question.eng: What steps does @data.characters.f1_father.name take to help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follow his instruction?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: He warns @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name that misbehaviour is not acceptable.

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Try again! Making the instruction positive by telling @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name what she should do rather than shouldn’t do will help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to follow through.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: He gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a transition warning & follows through with what he said.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Correct! All these steps make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follows @data.characters.f1_father.name’s instruction. He also praises his daughter.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: He makes @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name feel guilty for taking too long.

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Try again! Making her feel guilty will mean it is harder for @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to feel motivated to follow instructions both now and in the future. It will also feel stressful for @data.characters.f1_father.name.

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: He tells her to stop playing and start cleaning.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Try again! He gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a positive instruction to “clean up” without giving a negative one of “stop playing.”

quiz_3_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f1_father.name had said: “@data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name, stop playing with your blocks, and don’t go to bed with dirty teeth!”

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Exactly. It is important to give one positive instruction at a time. It makes a big difference.

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Try again! It’s important to give one positive instruction at a time. This will make the instruction easier to follow.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at another family to see how positive instructions can even help to prevent misbehaviour before it starts!

text_2.eng: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name  and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name are playing with a ball in the garden

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at another family to see how positive instructions can even help to prevent misbehaviour before it starts!
rows.text_2: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name  and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name are playing with a ball in the garden

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name please come and help your grandfather carry these grocery bags inside the house.

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name please come and help your grandfather carry these grocery bags inside the house.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you for coming to help me. Your grandmother is going to cook lots of delicious meals with the groceries.

rows.character_1_text: Thank you for coming to help me. Your grandmother is going to cook lots of delicious meals with the groceries.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name and @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name did here.

quiz_1_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name had not paid attention to the children?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: They would have played ball together.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Unlikely. The situation between the children would have gotten out of hand.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: They could have hurt each other in the argument.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Yes. The children could have gotten so upset that they would have hurt each other.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Nothing. @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name would have carried the bags inside the house.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Probably not. If @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name had kept quiet, she and @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name would have had to spend more time and energy trying to resolve the conflict.

quiz_2_question.eng: What does @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name do to prevent the argument from getting out of hand?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: She draws their attention away from the problem, involves them in a positive activity, and gives them praise.

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: That’s right. She quickly intervenes to distract them, and gives a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: She reminds them it’s important to get along.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Try again! She rather gives them a way to get along again by involving them in a positive activity.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: She gives them a warning for a consequence.

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Try again! Giving a consequence would not help them to resolve the conflict. Instead, giving them praise encourages them to continue their positive behaviour.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Unlikely. The situation between the children would have gotten out of hand.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Yes. The children could have gotten so upset that they would have hurt each other.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Probably not. If @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name had kept quiet, she and @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name would have had to spend more time and energy trying to resolve the conflict.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are building blocks to give positive instructions that work:

section_1_text.eng:
Make sure you have your child’s attention when giving an instruction. 

Move close to them, say their name, get down to their level and get them to look at you before giving the instruction.

Say the behaviour you want your child to do. Make your instructions positive, specific, and realistic.

Instructions should be a command instead of a question.

section_2_text.eng:
Give one instruction at a time.

Make sure your instruction is something your child can do.

Use transition warnings when changing activities. Example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can get ready for bed.”

section_3_text.eng:
Use positive words: instead of “Don’t shout,” say “Talk in a quiet voice.”

Give instructions in a calm, firm voice.

Act as if you expect your child to follow through.

Use “WHEN this, THEN that” to teach children the benefits of good behaviour.

Be kind to yourself—learning positive instructions takes practice!

section_4_text.eng:
Praise your child immediately after following an instruction

Use physical and verbal praise to support positive behaviour.

Also give your child instructions to do things that he/she is just about to do. Then he/she is following instructions without realising it, and you can then praise him or her.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are building blocks to give positive instructions that work:
rows.section_1_text:
Make sure you have your child’s attention when giving an instruction. 

Move close to them, say their name, get down to their level and get them to look at you before giving the instruction.

Say the behaviour you want your child to do. Make your instructions positive, specific, and realistic.

Instructions should be a command instead of a question.
rows.section_2_text:
Give one instruction at a time.

Make sure your instruction is something your child can do.

Use transition warnings when changing activities. Example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can get ready for bed.”
rows.section_3_text:
Use positive words: instead of “Don’t shout,” say “Talk in a quiet voice.”

Give instructions in a calm, firm voice.

Act as if you expect your child to follow through.

Use “WHEN this, THEN that” to teach children the benefits of good behaviour.

Be kind to yourself—learning positive instructions takes practice!
rows.section_4_text:
Praise your child immediately after following an instruction

Use physical and verbal praise to support positive behaviour.

Also give your child instructions to do things that he/she is just about to do. Then he/she is following instructions without realising it, and you can then praise him or her.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are building blocks for redirecting behaviours:

section_1_text.eng:
Use instructions to move your child from a negative behaviour to a positive one.

Try to catch the behaviour before it starts or very early.

For younger children, you can also physically redirect them.

section_2_text.eng:
Use energy and positivity to encourage the new behaviour.

Example: “Reem, bring the ball here so we can play together!”

section_3_text.eng:
Praise your child for the next positive behaviour, instead of revisiting the negative one. Example: “Such a wonderful throw, Ahmed!” Not: “I’m glad you didn’t whine about that.”

Use verbal praise and physical praise (like a hug) to reinforce positive behaviour.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are building blocks for redirecting behaviours:
rows.section_1_text:
Use instructions to move your child from a negative behaviour to a positive one.

Try to catch the behaviour before it starts or very early.

For younger children, you can also physically redirect them.
rows.section_2_text:
Use energy and positivity to encourage the new behaviour.

Example: “Reem, bring the ball here so we can play together!”
rows.section_3_text:
Praise your child for the next positive behaviour, instead of revisiting the negative one. Example: “Such a wonderful throw, Ahmed!” Not: “I’m glad you didn’t whine about that.”

Use verbal praise and physical praise (like a hug) to reinforce positive behaviour.

text_1_facilitator.eng: In order to practise giving instructions that work, we all need to work on turning our negative instructions into positive ones.

quiz_1_question.eng: Click on each of the negative commands to see how they can be restated as a positive instruction.

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: "Stop fighting with your siblings over toys!"

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: "Please take turns with toys! Each of you can have 5 minutes."

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: "Please speak with a quiet, indoor voice."

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: "Please keep your food on the plate."

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: "Please take turns with toys! Each of you can have 5 minutes."
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: "Please speak with a quiet, indoor voice."
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: "Please keep your food on the plate."
rows.quiz_1_question: Click on each of the negative commands to see how they can be restated as a positive instruction.
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: "Stop fighting with your siblings over toys!"
rows.text_1_facilitator: In order to practise giving instructions that work, we all need to work on turning our negative instructions into positive ones.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Ready to give it a go? Your home activity is to give your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions. 

Remember to give one instruction at a time and praise them. This will help your child to follow your instructions.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Of course, you can! It might feel awkward at first, but you will get it soon! Keep up the excellent effort.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to rephrase your requests. After the next request you give your child, stop and imagine how it could be rephrased as a positive request. You’ve got this!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Of course, you can! It might feel awkward at first, but you will get it soon! Keep up the excellent effort.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to rephrase your requests. After the next request you give your child, stop and imagine how it could be rephrased as a positive request. You’ve got this!
rows.text_1_facilitator:
Ready to give it a go? Your home activity is to give your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions. 

Remember to give one instruction at a time and praise them. This will help your child to follow your instructions.
